English: In the morning
Montignac
Enjoying the view?
Very much actually. Montignac is a beautiful city after all - the island' capital and its prized jewel. And it only took us two days to capture it.
Certainly better than the last time.

True. Let us not beat around the bush any longer. I don't wish to insult your intelligence, Lemontov.\nYou must have long figured out the first attack was just a small nudge, testing the waters, so to speak. To see if the NATO would take the bait.
I did suspect as much.
Of course you did. It was blatantly obvious. Although it did get past all those idiots in Kremlin.
You speak very brazenly.
We are far from the central government, Lemontov. We are more free than others. Free to pursue our own goals.

You might not be fully aware that after Livanokh the Kolguyev garrison was reduced to only a token force.\nThe peace treaty required it. It was done to make sure we never threaten local stability again.
What changed?

The American intervention on Everon, of course. Their military buildup and expansion had to be answered - we received more men.\nNot enough to mount a serious attack, but enough to create new opportunities.

A good plan  - my own I might add. But even when the enemy marched on Kolguyev, the Kremlin lost balls.\nI had to make sure our situation weas truly hopeless for them to finally budge and grant us the resources we required.
The attack in central Kolguyev... You groveling before Volkov... all this time, your incompetence was just a play?
I thought you would see through it. It brings me joy to know I managed to deceive the great Grigory Lemontov.
A great feat indeed. Tell me then, what do you need this army for?
You are aware, of course, that Everon is not our final goal. This story does not end here. It is Malden and it has always been Malden.
But what is there I am not at liberty to disclose to you at this moment. But follow us and you shall find out for yourself eventually.
Now, I laid my cards on the table so that you are aware of the situation and who you are dealing with. Come in, we need to discuss the next phase.

I'm going to go straigth to the point. The rebel commander, Gaston, came to us and requested our help. Apparently, a lot of their men were captured and taken prisoner - including their second in command, one Poincare.
We found where they are held. Your task is to join forces with the rebels and help them reclaim those prisoners.
Sounds easy enough.
That's not all. Once you rescue them, kill them.
They are relentless, they fight for their beliefs no matter the opposition and they shall never stop. \nThey are a hindrance and dangerous one at that.
Either we deal with them now or they are going to cause us problems in the long run. Executing their highest command should do the trick.
So you wish to screw over them the second time? And again hiding behiind the mask of friendship while stabbing them in the back?
You tried to deal with them in the past and look how that turned out. You failed to get rid of their leaders, that's where you erred.\nBut we've got both of them in once place this time.
And friends? Please. Temporary co-belligerents is more likely. They will turn on us the moment the NATO is gone. We shall just turn on them first.
It's one thing to defeat them in battle. It's another to slaughter them like animals when they can't even defend themselves.
You are deceiving yourself if you think this is any more different than what you did seven years ago with Livanokh.\nI'm just asking you to finish the job you already started.
Look, Lemontov, this order came straight from comrade Volkov and it's not up for discussion. He wants you to do it personally.
What's the position of Kremlin on this?
I don't know, you would have to ask them.
I take it they did not sanction it then.
For fuck's sake, Lemontov, of course not! Kremlin has no power here! On this island, my word is as much worth as that of the General Secretary!\nHere, you only answer to me.
Still need convincing? You know, I am long looking for an excuse to put a bullet in your head. Will you give me one?
I'll do it, of course. My loyalty is yours, comrade Zubarev.
We shall see about that. A meeting with the rebels, tomorrow morning here. Don't be late. Dismissed!
Piece of shit... Volkov's yes man, my ass. I have to talk to Stas, things are moving quickly.
Grigory! Hey, Grigory!
Sergei! What happened to you to end up in the hospital?
Le Moule happened. Tough fight. We almost had to retreat but an ace pilot saved our asses. What about you?
Me? Yeah, I'm alright. Listen, can we talk more privately? Let's go over there for a second.
I thought we should not talk discreetly in public.
Sergei, listen, something terrible is about to happen. The rebels need our help rescuing their comrades from prison.\nWe are to provide assistance tomorrow.
That's terrible how?
We are to... execute them right after.
Wh...What?
Zubarer just told me. Apparently, a direct order from Volkov. They want to finish the Everon resistance for good.
Well, you're not going to do it, are you?
What am I supposed to do, Sergei? It's a direct order. If I don't do it, they find someone else and I'm going to the tribunal.\nOr better yet, straight in front of the firing squad!
Grigory, you cannot do this!
I must do it! Do you not see?!
They are our allies! They've been fighting for their lifes, for their freedom for years - and you're going to slaughter them like animals? Cowardly stabbing them in the back?!
What other choice do I have, Sergei?
You can choose not to do it!
Then it's my head on the chopping block! How does that solve anything!?
This is certainly a war crime! Orders like this have to go through the Politburo.
Sergei, the government holds no power here. Volkov and Zubarev are calling all the shots.
What about making our move then? What about we march in and shoot down Zubarev, Volkov and all the others? Take matters into our own hands.
That's folly, Sergei. Volkov isn't even here! The army will see us as mutineers and traitors. We would be lucky to even get close to Zubarev.\nNo, this is not yet the time to strike.

It's always waiting with you, Grigory! We are still waiting, still biding our time, still expecting some new information to shed a light on the fact we are completele fucked. When is it going to be the time to act?!
We would die pointless deaths if we are not ready. It will not be on Everon, Sergei.
So you're waiting for Malden then. Expecting the grand reveal of their goal to solve everything? And you're willing to let the rebels die for it?
This is not what I would have wanted, but if that's what it takes - yes.
I cannot believe this. I fought with them, Grigory. They saved my life!
I am sorry, Sergei, but if they must be killed in order to save the world then we cannot hesitate!
I've never been this disappointed in anyone. I thought you were better, Grigory. If you must do it, so be it. But don't come anywhere near me ever again.
Sergei! Sergei?!
Your car is ready, comrade major.
I slept terribly.
Did I even sleep? The whole night feels like a fever dream to me.
What am I even doing? What am I going to do?
Executing the rebels.. I feel sick. Sergei's pissed, understandably. What can we do against orders though? Zubarev was clear it's my head or theirs.
He played me like a fiddle. Of course he is not a bumbling idiot, I am the idiot!
I underestimated him badly. How could it happen? I normally see right through people. My perception is in the shitter.
This must not happen again. Mistake like this can cost us everything!
But of what this? One thing is to kill in war, another is to stab in the back. Like some underhanded rogue. The worst kind of a two-faced shakal.
I feel worse than shit. And the day has barely started.
Is there a way to save them? Hardly, I'm going to be watched by my own team. Kaplinsky probably has strict orders - if I let them go, I'm going to get a bullet in the back of my head.
This is so shit! I feel so powerless. A murder is about to happen and I am to be the main perpetrator. And I can't do anything about it.
I must stop Volkov and Zubarev from reaching their goal on Malden. Do I have to become a war criminal to do that?\nThis is probably their game to test my loyalties.
Fuck this shit. I am Grigory Lemontov, goddamit! I did not come this far to fail. Fuck you, Zubarev, two can play that game.
Comrade major, we've been waiting for you. Our squad is ready. This is Gaston Astier and his people. They understand English.
You truly do give us the best. After your performance at our castle, I'm looking forward to working with you, Lemontov.
Likewise. Let's get to it. What do we have?
A small mechanized squad is preparing to attack Entre Deux. We can go with them to get closer to our target.
The prisoners are kept at a coastal base in the east. There are two roads leading there.
We should avoid the southern front and large bases, otherwise it shouldn't be an issue. We are ready to go if you are.
I'm taking the rebels with me. You join the attack on Entre Deux and then get ready to join us at the base. I'll give you the signal.
I'm not sure, comrade major, I have my orders...
I have mine too. This is the best way to fulfill them.
I think I understand, comrade. Very well, we're going in on your signal.
What's the plan?
You're going to follow me. First stop is Entre Deux, then your friends.
Hold on, who says we want to follow your orders? My men will not like it.

Listen here, Gaston, and listen well. You will follow and you will obey.\nYou are not on the best terms with our command.\nYou do what I say and we are all going to be happy at the end of this. Got it?
Our position is indeed bad if we have to ask the Soviets for any help. But I do hold you in higher regard than most of your countrymen.\nVery well, we're going with you.
We follow Lemontov!
Let's get moving then. Kaplinsky, on me. Gaston, we're going to Entre Deux and then to the base. You are free to follow or find your own way. Wait for our signal, we attack the base together.
I like that plan. We'll be in touch.
Spetsnaz, on Lemontov!
You again are getting me out of prison, Gaston. For the second time now.
Don't get used to it, Jean. I'm getting old and I might not be there for you the third time!
You had to ask the Soviets for help?
It was either your life or my pride. It was not a hard desicion. And they delivered.
I don't like it. We should get out of here.
American patrols! We need to move!
Where to, Lemontov?
Back into the forest. Let's go.
To the boats in the port. Quickly!
You helped us out, Soviets. We expected much, much less from you. So thank you.
Comrade major?
This is nothing personal, Gaston. And I am truly sorry for what I'm about to do.
Open fire!
Into the boats, rebels, now!
What's going on, Lemontov?
You are to take your men and leave Everon for a few weeks at least. Get onto one of the small islands around and stay there.
What are you saying?
My official orders are to execute you here and now. I am not going to do that. We got rid of all the witnesses, so get on that boat if you wish to see the next sunrise!
Let's go! Let's go!
You truly have grand character, Lemontov
Go, Gaston! Before my own men show up.
We owe you, Lemontov. Thank you. Good luck on your path!
Comrade major! Over here!
We heard gunshots. Have you done the deed?
Yes, they're dead.
You killed them all on your own?
It's easier when they turn their back to you. It also helped they trusted me, after I led them all morning.
I must say that was ingenious. You truly are the greatest Spetsnaz.
Good work, comrade major. Your loyalty will not go unnoticed. Let's go back!
IVAN TO DMITRI, WE'RE MOVING INTO POSITION TO SEIZE ENTRE DEUX. CALL US IN WHEN YOU WANT, BUT IF WE DO NOT RECEIVE YOUR SIGNAL WE ARE GOING IN REGARDLESS. OUT.
DMITRI TO IVAN, YOU HAVE YOUR SIGNAL. OVER.
IVAN UNDERSTOOD. WE'RE ATTACKING ENTRE DEUX. OUT.
IVAN TO DMITRI, WE'RE BEGGINING OUR ATTACK ON ENTRE DEUX. OUT.
IVAN TO DMITRI, ENTRE DEUX HAS BEEN SEIZED. WE'RE GOING TO HOLD OUR POSITIONS HERE. OUT.

ROMAN TO DMITRI, THIS KAPLINSKY, COMRADE MAJOR. WE'RE IN ENTRE DEUX. WE'RE GOING TO DELAY A WHILE TO SEE WHERE THE ENEMY IS CONCENTRATING AND THEN MOVE OUT. WE'LL CALL YOU ONCE WE HAVE THE BASE IN OUR SIGHTS. OUT.
SPARROW TO DMITRI, WE'RE ALSO IN ENTRE DEUX. WE'RE GOING TO DELAY A WHILE, SEE WHERE THE ENEMY CONCENTRATES FORCES. WE WILL BE ON THE COAST BY THE TIME YOU GET THERE, DON'T WORRY. OUT.
ROMAN TO DMITRI, WE'RE IN POSITION. CALL US IN WHENEVER. OUT.
ROMAN TO DMITRI, WE'RE STILL WAITING FOR YOUR SIGNAL. WHENEVER YOU'RE READY. OUT.
ROMAN TO DMITRI, ENEMY PATROLS FROM THE NORTH! WE HAVE TO RETREAT TOWARDS THE FOREST, BE CAREFUL DOWN THERE! OUT.
SPARROW TO DMITRI, WE ARE IN PLACE AND WAITING FOR YOUR SIGNAL. OUT.
LET'S GO, SPARROW. TIME TO RESCUE YOUR PEOPLE. OVER.
WE'LL SEE YOU THERE. OUT.
THE BASE IS OURS. GET THE PRISONERS FROM THEIR CELLS AND LET'S GET THE HELL OUT OF HERE.
Sparrow
Rescue Prisoners
Meet with the Rebels
Soviet Attack
Sparrow
Roman
Enemy Camp
Enemy Camp
Take the Soviet Spetsnaz as your squad
Take the French rebels as your squad
Retreat to the forests
Retreat to the boats
